title: Ensure on-disk passwords are unencrypted
body:
This is a step towards removing password encryption alltogether.

The background is that password encryption is broken on Android Nougat anyway, and that it
didn't provide any extra security before that either.

Since Bankdroid needs to send plain text passwords to the banks, it must
be possible to retrieve the plain text passwords automatically. And if
the passwords are encrypted on disk, Bankdroid needs to have the key.
And if Bankdroid stores both the key and the encrypted password on the
phone, a determined attacker could get both anyway, and the encryption
is useless.

The only thing the encryption has protected against is a user rooting
their own device and retrieving their own plain text passwords. This
would enable the attacker to read their own account balance from the
bank.

Which they likely already could even before this change...

This change also disables an Android Lint check whose outcome changes
over time; these checks are impossible to maintain. And we fixed some
warnings.

title: allow "panic button" apps to lock Bankdroid
body:
We (Guardian Project) have been developing "panic button" features in our apps for years, and now we are working to make a more flexible and open ecosystem of apps that can both trigger other apps, or respond to triggers. Since banking should be as private as possible, Bankdroid is a natural panic responder app, for example, by having Bankdroid lock when the "Pattern Lock" is enabled and a panic message is received. This setup allows for easy configuration of a single trigger action which can then trigger multiple apps.

You can see an example of this user experience in this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mS1gstS6YS8

It is simple to implement, here are some examples of other apps:
- https://github.com/SMSSecure/SMSSecure/pull/290
- https://github.com/theScrabi/NewPipe/pull/133
- https://github.com/bpellin/keepassdroid/pull/72

The first panic button app that sends this kind of trigger is called Ripple, and it is available here:
https://github.com/guardianproject/ripple
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=info.guardianproject.ripple

I'm adding support to this app right now:
https://panicbutton.io/
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.iilab.pb

More info on the panic kit work here:
https://dev.guardianproject.info/projects/panic/wiki

title: Reintroduce Jojo without account-login
label: [Label(name="Feature")]
body:
The Jojo (Skånetrafiken) accounts I had configured stopped working some months ago and as a user I would have no notification of that it was due to a Bankdroid change, even less that it was an unnecessary breakage. 

See the commit:
https://github.com/liato/android-bankdroid/commit/c52399a8105ff29e951e204119966fa1dd90764a

I prefer the Jojo no-login access over the require-account-to-login variant introduced in that commit. Thus I suggest that instead of _changing_ JOJO it should have been _adding_ another account. (As in this case it was a feature request, it should be a rule of thumb not to break what was already working.)

The previously used link is still working fine so it would be a simple matter of re-introducing the old implementation. 

https://www.shop.skanetrafiken.se/kollasaldo.html

(Question is if it also should be an intelligent change that would detect if the stored "account" is an email or a card number, so that those, like me, that have not edited the account will have a functioning app automatically.)

Seeing that I haven't contributed this change yet, I likely won't come around doing it either. :-(

I would be willing to "donate" a Jojo card (number and CVC) to Bankdroid if anyone is interested of maintaining or setting up a testbench. Just let me know and I can email it or post it here. 

PS. I also sent Skånetrafiken a question asking if they were planning to remove that support and if they would consider collaborating with Bankdroid so you could get notifications of planned changes directly from the source. The answer was kind of "no to both questions":

"Skånetrafiken har inga planer på att ta bort möjligheten att kontrollera saldo utan inloggning. Inom kort kommer vi att lansera en ny hemsida som är mobilanpassad vilket innebär att alla funktioner kommer att funka optimalt vid användning i mobilen. I dagsläget har vi inga planer på att ta fram en app för kontroll av saldo osv. Vi jobbar ständigt med att förbättra och utveckla våra produkter och tjänster så det är inte omöjligt att det kommer i framtiden.

Skånetrafiken har inget samarbete med andra app-tillverkare (te.x. för Bankdroid). Vilka funktioner de erbjuder och om de kräver inloggning eller ej är inget som vi styr eller kontrollerar."

On a side topic the mentioned "new web" is something that might break the Jojo support both temporarily and long-term. Possibly just an URL change, possibly something more. May be good to know if you get complaints.

"Inom kort lanseras vår nya hemsida och då kommer ditt konto på Jojo Online att flyttas till vår nya och förbättrade webbshop kallad ”E-tjänster”. 

[...]

Efter lanseringen flyttas ditt konto och dina uppgifter till vår nya hemsida och du får då ett mejl med en länk där du får aktivera ditt konto och välja ett nytt lösenord.

[...]

Ett par dagar före flytten kommer tjänsterna för att köpa kort, ladda kort, registrera kort och skapa konto att stängas på Jojo Online. Du kommer fortfarande att kunna se ditt saldo och spärra redan registrerade kort."

title: Usage of Swedbanks EasyLogin API
label: [Label(name="Bank"), Label(name="Feature")]
body:
As the personal number is of the sensitive side it would be good if Bankdroid didn't store the personal number if it isn't needed. Swedbank have the EasyLogin API that works as following.
1. User logs in with any of Swedbank authentication methods
2. A call to the Easy Login service returns a easy login token which is a randomized token that is in Swedbanks system translated to the personal number of user that is currently logged in.
3. Next time the user needs to login the easy login token can be sent instead of the personal number.

This means that for Swedbank and Savingsbank only users there is no need to actually store the personal number of the user on the device.

The new Swedbank API ( #309 ) requires a unique identification per installation.

> The unique device id should be generated by the client the first time a customers uses the app and should never be changed as long as the app is installed. Best approch is to create a UUID first time the app is being used and store it permanently on the dedicated app storage on the device and make sure that all requests from that app instance contains this UUID in the Authorization header.

Check upon application start if a unique id is stored on the device, otherwise create one. See http://android-developers.blogspot.se/2011/03/identifying-app-installations.html for an example.

title: Nordea parsing needs to be changed ASAP
body:
Hi,

I'm not sure if you are aware, but Nordea is closing down their "mobile.nordea.se"-site at the end of June. This means that Bankdroid will probably stop working for Nordea in about 20 days. 
The pull request from @goober on #242 seems to be a nice way to go, unfortunately I think Nordea has updated their API and that the solution is not usable without some modification. The new API requires the user to authenticate with Mobilt BankID or eCode at least once, to be able to use personal pin in the future.

I started a conversation with Nordea regarding access to their documentation and API, but unfortunately they would not allow third party developers access to it. I've also tried reversing the mobile application to figure out how it communicates with the API, but that is taking to much time.

There is also another possible way to go, and that is scraping nordea.se, there is a pull request for that as well, by @rhoot on #125.

Best regards,
Robin

title: Vad ska "balance" visa? Det är inte konsekvent.
body:
För ett bankkonto är det enkelt eftersom det enbart (vanligtvis) har positivt saldo eftersom banken stoppar övertrasseringar. För dessa visar vi alltid saldo = "kvar att handla för".

Men vilket belopp ska visas för kreditkort/betalkort? Här har vi ju:
1. ett saldo (som vanligtvis är negativt)
2. en kreditgräns
att bolla med.

Exempel:
Anta att jag med kort X har en kreditgräns på 10000kr, har handlat för 100kr och inte har gjort några förskottsinbetalningar.
Vad ska vi visa för "balance" för då?
Den "bank" som jag har gjort (Everydaycard) visar -100 (= saldo).
En annan "bank" som jag har (Volvofinans) visar 9900 (="kvar att handla för" = kreditgräns + saldo).

Vad är rätt?  Jag tycker att saldo är rätt att visa.
Hur ser det ut för övriga "banker"?
Ska det vara en konfiguration om "kvar att handla för" eller "saldo" ska visas?

body:
Hi!

I am a customer of Nordea DK. Most customers do not use their old code system (with cpr-number and 8-12 digit code), but the national Danish system Nem-ID. If you have a Nem-ID login, you need a key card to log on to their internet bank, but for their "Netbank konto-kik" (where you only can see your account statements, but not perform transactions) you only need your username (can consist of letters and/or digits) and password (can consist of letters and digits and special symbols). Since the Nordea DK version of Bankdroid only allows for digits in these, I cannot log in to my account with Bankdroid.

It would be really nice if this is fixed in a future version!

Thanks for a nice app (which I use for my Swedish Nordea account).

title: Support for banks with one-time passwords
label: [Label(name="Feature"), Label(name="wontfix")]
body:
Some banks such as Nordea Finland use one-time passwords for extra security unlike Nordea Sweden which uses the SSN and password. It would be nice to add support these one-time passwords. One way to do this would be to provide notifications to user which upon being clicked, displays a password prompt. The user then types in the one-time password and the account balance and transactions are then updated. This would make the app more accessible to more developers who then support other Nordic banks with one-time passwords.

Another way would be to allow the user to store all the one-time passwords in the system.

title: UI support for pairing API-keys for Content provider from 3rd pary apps
label: [Label(name="Feature")]
body:
The current implementation of copying the API-key from Bankdroid into an companion app has usability and adoption issues. 

I propose a functionality where a companion app like Ekonomipuls can send an explicit intent to BankDroid requesting access. BankDroid will then present the user with a screen that explains the implications and an accept button. An API-key will then have been exchanged and allow access to the BankDroid content provider.

The API-key should either come from the companinon app or be provider by BankDroid to the companion app.
